Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Restore FAILS with <RuntimeIdentifiers> set and <PackageReference> to BOTH NS 1.x + 2.0" (#6457) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @ogreenz on December 4, 2017 14:4_

Repro repo:
https://github.com/ogreenz/rid-netstandard2-repro

`dotnet --info`:

```
dotnet --info
.NET Command Line Tools (2.0.3)

Product Information:
 Version:            2.0.3
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  12f0c7efcc

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.16299
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.0.3\

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 2.0.3
  Build    : a9190d4a75f4a982ae4b4fa8d1a24526566c69df
```

Project references both NodaTime (NS 1.x) and Dapper (NS 2.0).

When built WITHOUT `<RuntimeIdentifiers>` in the .csproj `dotnet restore` runs to completion and restore is successfull.

When `<RuntimeIdentifiers>` is set to any valid value AND both packages are referenced/used restore fails with these cryptic messages:

```
$ dotnet restore
  Restoring packages for C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj...
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605: Detected package downgrade: System.IO.FileSystem.Primitives from 4.3.0 to 4.0.1. Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version.
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.IO.FileSystem 4.0.1 -> runtime.win.System.IO.FileSystem 4.3.0 -> System.IO.FileSystem.Primitives (>= 4.3.0)
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.IO.FileSystem.Primitives (>= 4.0.1)
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605: Detected package downgrade: System.Resources.ResourceManager from 4.3.0 to 4.0.1. Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version.
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.IO.FileSystem 4.0.1 -> runtime.win.System.IO.FileSystem 4.3.0 -> System.Resources.ResourceManager (>= 4.3.0)
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.Resources.ResourceManager (>= 4.0.1)
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605: Detected package downgrade: System.Runtime.Handles from 4.3.0 to 4.0.1. Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version.
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.IO.FileSystem 4.0.1 -> runtime.win.System.IO.FileSystem 4.3.0 -> System.Runtime.Handles (>= 4.3.0)
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.IO.FileSystem 4.0.1 -> System.Runtime.Handles (>= 4.0.1)
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605: Detected package downgrade: System.Runtime.InteropServices from 4.3.0 to 4.1.0. Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version.
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.IO.FileSystem 4.0.1 -> runtime.win.System.IO.FileSystem 4.3.0 -> System.Runtime.InteropServices (>= 4.3.0)
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.Runtime.InteropServices (>= 4.1.0)
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605: Detected package downgrade: System.Text.Encoding.Extensions from 4.3.0 to 4.0.11. Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version.
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.IO.FileSystem 4.0.1 -> runtime.win.System.IO.FileSystem 4.3.0 -> System.Text.Encoding.Extensions (>= 4.3.0)
C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj : error NU1605:  repro-netstandard -> NodaTime 2.2.3 -> System.Runtime.Serialization.Xml 4.1.1 -> System.Xml.ReaderWriter 4.0.11 -> System.Text.Encoding.Extensions (>= 4.0.11)
  Generating MSBuild file C:\projects\repro-netstandard\obj\repro-netstandard.csproj.nuget.g.props.
  Restore failed in 378 ms for C:\projects\repro-netstandard\repro-netstandard.csproj.
```

Note that if Dapper / NodaTime are used exclusively dotnet restore while using `<RuntimeIdentifiers>` runs successfully again....

_Copied from original issue: dotnet/sdk#1792_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Signing:  X509ChainElement.Certificate not disposed immediately after use" (#6464) at NuGet/Home

Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet "Updates" tab sometimes freezes when it's looking at a local folder. It doesn't always do this, but it's common enough to be annoying. Please don't ask me to give more information. I cannot. Not least because NuGet doesn't give any feedback or produce any useful logs for me to send you. _This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/164682/nuget-freezes.html VSTS ticketId: 536181_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Justin Emgarten [MSFT] on ‎12‎/‎15‎/‎2017, 03:01 PM (35 days ago):

How many packages are in the local folder?

How many MB total is the local folder?

Is this a flat folder of nupkgs, or is it using the v3 format of id\version\?

Maria Ghiondea [MSFT] on ‎12‎/‎15‎/‎2017, 04:13 PM (34 days ago):

Thank you for your feedback! For us to investigate this further, could you please provide on the contents of the local folder and how long the freeze occurs. We look forward to hearing from you!

_These are the original issue solutions:_ Dan solved on ‎12‎/‎16‎/‎2017, 02:40 AM (34 days ago), 0 votes:

At the moment, there are 73 packages in the local folder. It varies as I use it as a store for the packages that I build from github. The package names vary. Here's a sample of some typical ones (produced by the Orleans build):

10/12/2017  09:58            12,460 Microsoft.Orleans.Client.2.0.0-dev-201712100954.nupkg
10/12/2017  09:58            12,962 Microsoft.Orleans.Client.2.0.0-dev-201712100954.symbols.nupkg
14/12/2017  10:38            12,457 Microsoft.Orleans.Client.2.0.0-dev-201712141034.nupkg
14/12/2017  10:38            12,960 Microsoft.Orleans.Client.2.0.0-dev-201712141034.symbols.nupkg
10/12/2017  09:58            63,618 Microsoft.Orleans.Clustering.AzureStorage.2.0.0-dev-201712100954.nupkg
10/12/2017  09:58           159,966 Microsoft.Orleans.Clustering.AzureStorage.2.0.0-dev-201712100954.symbols.nupkg
14/12/2017  10:38            56,245 Microsoft.Orleans.Clustering.AzureStorage.2.0.0-dev-201712141034.nupkg
14/12/2017  10:38           145,679 Microsoft.Orleans.Clustering.AzureStorage.2.0.0-dev-201712141034.symbols.nupkg
10/12/2017  09:58            22,552 Microsoft.Orleans.Clustering.ServiceFabric.2.0.0-dev-201712100954.nupkg
10/12/2017  09:58            64,369 Microsoft.Orleans.Clustering.ServiceFabric.2.0.0-dev-201712100954.symbols.nupkg
14/12/2017  10:38            22,541 Microsoft.Orleans.Clustering.ServiceFabric.2.0.0-dev-201712141034.nupkg

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget flaking out while -reinstall packages" (#6469) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
i moved some projects into subfolders and readded them to the solution, then in package manager console ran `update-package -reinstall` to fix the references. After a few seconds, the message "undoing <some file>" started flickering in the status bar, with a new file each time and about 1-2 seconds apart. This continued for a few minutes and came to a Yes/No file overwrite prompt. Thats when I started the attached recording. Another minute or so later the error "Destination array is not long enough to copy all the items in the collection. Check array index and length." popped up. After acknowledging it, it continued to flicker the "undoing" message for a few more minutes before the reinstall was complete. Why did this take so long, and whats the error about? _This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/169383/nuget-flaking-out-while-reinstall-packages.html VSTS ticketId: 541015_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Ankit Mishra [MSFT] on ‎12‎/‎18‎/‎2017, 06:05 PM (31 days ago):

Thank you for your feedback! For us to investigate this further, could you please provide the following -


  1. A sample project that has this problem
  2. Repro steps that we could follow to reproduce this?


We look forward to hearing from you!

Andrew Stanton on ‎12‎/‎19‎/‎2017, 04:37 AM (31 days ago):

@Ankit Mishra [MSFT] - I uploaded a bunch of logs and outputs and screenshots, as well as explaining the scenario.

What did you find when trying to reproduce this and analyzing the logs?

Andrew Stanton on ‎12‎/‎27‎/‎2017, 06:16 AM (23 days ago): I responded to this days ago. Andrew Stanton on ‎1‎/‎5‎/‎2018, 06:30 AM (14 days ago):

Where is the response nagging app that works in the other direction?

Andrew Stanton on ‎1‎/‎8‎/‎2018, 11:09 AM (11 days ago):

@Ankit Mishra [MSFT] - I have had another occurrence of this, but without the error message.


https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/178543/update-package-reinstall-for-a-single-project-make.html


Has the feedback collection recording, a memory dump, and the PMC log attached.

_These are the original issue solutions:_ (no solutions)

Events.RelatedBody:

Thank you for your feedback! For us to investigate this further, could you please provide the following -


  1. A sample project that has this issue.
  2. Exact repro steps on that sample project that we could use to repro this problem.


We look forward to hearing from you!

Darrell Tunnell on ‎12‎/‎19‎/‎2017, 06:45 AM (31 days ago): Trying to update some nuget packages and am getting this error.I have attached image of output. Samantha Houts [MSFT] on ‎12‎/‎20‎/‎2017, 08:09 PM (29 days ago):

I got this with

https://developer.xamarin.com/samples/xamarin-forms/TodoLocalized/

Update the Android project's compile version to 8.0 first, then try to update the Xamarin.Android.Support libraries.

Ibrahim Cohen on ‎12‎/‎26‎/‎2017, 00:17 PM (24 days ago):

Getting the same error while attempting to update xamarin packages, also getting:
SeverityCodeDescriptionProjectFileLineSuppression State ErrorThis project references NuGet package(s) that are missing on this computer. Use NuGet Package Restore to download them. For more information, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=322105. The missing file is ..\..\packages\Xamarin.Android.Support.v4.26.1.0.1\build\MonoAndroid80\Xamarin.Android.Support.v4.targets.SolutionName.AndroidC:\Workspace\Sample\App Test\SolutionName\SolutionName\SolutionName.Android\SolutionName.Android.csproj383

_These are the original issue solutions:_ Hines Vaughan solved on ‎12‎/‎26‎/‎2017, 00:37 PM (24 days ago), 1 votes:

Was receiving this issue as well just now. Went into VS settings -> NuGet settings -> cleared the NuGet cache, closed Visual Studio, and then I deleted all obj and bin folders.

Ibrahim Cohen solved on ‎12‎/‎26‎/‎2017, 00:54 PM (24 days ago), 0 votes:

That worked, thank you Hines Vaughan!!

Ignacio Ortiz solved on ‎1‎/‎10‎/‎2018, 10:04 AM (9 days ago), 0 votes:

What worked for me was this:

1. Deleted Nuget Cache on VS.

2. Opened packages folder and deleted all packages and dependencies manually.

3. Same thing with .csproj file and packages.config files.

4. Reloaded the project again and started to install one by one the dependencies starting for the dependencies that didn't have any subsequent dependency. I installed using Nuget Package Manager and got the famous error "This collection is read-only", then simply clicked again in INSTALL in Nuget and the second time it installed correctly. It's important to verify no traces of previous versions or wrong dependencies are in packages folder, packages.config file and .csproj file.

That's it. Hope it helps.

Paul Diston solved on ‎1‎/‎12‎/‎2018, 07:15 AM (7 days ago), 0 votes:

I am experiencing this problem again today however clearing the NuGet cache, deleting all obj and bin directories and clearing the Packages directory do not seem to be working.

Update: After further investigation, I have got the This collection is read-only because I was trying to install Xamarin.Forms via NuGet however the reference was already added after I added a reference to another project that already had Xamarin.Forms installed.

Paul Diston on ‎1‎/‎12‎/‎2018, 08:10 AM (7 days ago):

Update 2: The above update seems to be incorrect, I am still getting This collection is read-only, even when the project I am trying to install Xamarin.Forms into does not reference other projects.

Hines Vaughan on ‎1‎/‎12‎/‎2018, 08:36 AM (7 days ago):

Have you tried using Package Manager Console window instead of the normal NuGet GUI window in VS? I can't remember exactly but I know some people had success with Package Manager Console while the normal NuGet GUI window was failing.

Darrell Tunnell on ‎1‎/‎12‎/‎2018, 09:30 AM (7 days ago):

I have tried using package manager console. I get the same issue. It seems to fail on the Xamarin.Forms package - here is the log output around the issue:

>

Successfully installed 'Xamarin.Android.Support.v7.MediaRouter 26.1.0.1' to Todo.Android

Install failed. Rolling back...
Package 'Xamarin.Forms 2.5.0.122203' does not exist in project 'Todo.Android'

Events.RelatedBody:
See https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/63124/not-possible-to-set-versionprefix-for-dotnet-stand.html?childToView=170779#comment-170779 The problem is still there... When we edit via project properties, the gui read the VersionPrefix property but will save it to <Version> properties... "Dotnet pack ... --version-suffix alpha" will not work after that... _This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/171568/not-possible-to-set-versionprefix-for-dotnet-stand-1.html VSTS ticketId: 542458_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Ankit Mishra [MSFT] on ‎12‎/‎21‎/‎2017, 03:03 PM (28 days ago):

Thank you for your feedback! For us to investigate this further, could you please provide the exact place where you are adding VersionSuffix in Visual Studio GUI?


We look forward to hearing from you!

Guy Bournival on ‎12‎/‎21‎/‎2017, 04:21 PM (28 days ago):

I didn't add VersionSuffix with Visual Studio GUI. I added only VersionPrefix by editing .csproj with a text editor... VersionSuffix's value come from $Build.BuildId. VersionSuffix is set with this command: "dotnet pack ... --no-build --version-suffix $build.BuildId". This command is in a docker-compose.ci.build.yml who is call from a VSTS docker-compose task.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue " [nuget] Unable to find package 'XXX' at source ''" (#6466) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi, PM> Install-Package XXX returns this error: Unable to find package 'XXX' at source '' when the Package Source is "All". This happen on my work computer (big company) where we have also private NuGet repositories. The problem exists also using the Package Manager Visual Tool, I just reported the console version because it is more clear. The problem is not recent, I noticed it for some months... for sure with the first release of VS 2017 (maybe also VS 2015, I don't remember) Visual Studio 2017 Pro (continuosly updated to last version) Workaround: Select "nuget.org" in "Package source". Note. Using -Source parameter: (PM> Install-Package XXX -Source nuget.org) does not work. _This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/177504/nuget-unable-to-find-package-xxx-at-source.html VSTS ticketId: 547534_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Nikolche Kolev [MSFT] on ‎1‎/‎8‎/‎2018, 01:20 PM (11 days ago):

Thank you for your feedback! For us to investigate this further, could you please provide a copy of your nuget.config? Or at least a screenshot of the package source tab in Visual Studio. We look forward to hearing from you!

Alessandro Piccione on ‎1‎/‎9‎/‎2018, 01:15 AM (10 days ago):

I created a solution with 4 projects.

maxthonsnap20180109090120.png

The main project is a .Net Core Web API.
I tried to add Swagger to it.
The package name is "Swashbuckle.AspNetCore".
That is the package that generated the problem but, as I said, it happens with any package.

There is not a nuget.config file.

I think this is the "package source tab" you need to see:

package-source-settings.png

My VS configuration is fine (I work on more than 50 different solutions without problems) and it is OK when you switch from "All" to "nuget.org".
I noticed this same behavior on the pc of another developer (another team in the company).

_These are the original issue solutions:_ (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget package update reformats config files poorly" (#6465) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
It forces xml attributes for an element to all be on one line, making me have to scroll 300+ columns to the right to read the settings. It should leave that stuff alone and just touch the parts it is supposed to. It also adds encoding to the declaration if its missing. I don't think I need that either. Screenshot attached of some of its worse offenses. _This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/182303/nuget-package-update-reformats-config-files-poorly.html VSTS ticketId: 551762_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Patricio Beltran Saldivar [MSFT] on ‎1‎/‎16‎/‎2018, 11:52 AM (3 days ago):

Thank you for your feedback! For us to investigate this further, could you please provide a solution where we could repro this issue or some clear steps to get this issue? (e.g. file new project -> do this -> see the issue). We look forward to hearing from you!

Andrew Stanton on ‎1‎/‎16‎/‎2018, 09:22 PM (2 days ago): Wasn't there a screenshot of what it did to my config files attached? Patricio Beltran Saldivar [MSFT] on ‎1‎/‎17‎/‎2018, 10:00 AM (2 days ago):

Yes, there was a screenshot of the config file. This is not a usual behavior, and the reason that I ask for some repro steps is so that I can understand what is causing that behavior and have more knowledge on what the problem is. Could you please provide with a sample solution or some steps for me to get a solution to reproduce this issue? Thanks!

Andrew Stanton on ‎1‎/‎17‎/‎2018, 01:25 PM (2 days ago):

database3.zip - this is an example solution with two projects - one class library and one console app. The console app refs the class library. Both have EnterpriseLibrary.Data 5.0 installed. The console app.config has a formatted wcf client endpoint and an app setting without a space before the closing bracket.

if you update the class library to use EL 6.0, nuget adds an assembly binding redirect in the app config. It also reformats the file adding a space before the closing bracket and collapsing the wcf client endpoint into a single line. With a simple example this may not seem so bad, but in a config file with 200+ lines the diff ends up looking like the one attached to the issue report.

A copy of the original app.config is in the console app as well.

_These are the original issue solutions:_ (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecating the ability to copy Full access API keys" (#16) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|*None*|[NuGet/NuGetGallery#5231](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5231)|

We on the NuGet.org team are committed to continually seek ways to improve the security of our services. A year ago, we introduced [scoped API keys](https://blog.nuget.org/20170202/introducing-scoped-api-keys.html) to help our users better manage their API keys. While we recommend the use of scoped API keys, we will continue to support our legacy 'Full access API keys' that were previously granted by the service. Such keys do not expire if you use them at least one every 365 days to push a package.
 
We are making a change to our service such that a newly issued API key cannot be copied after the page is refreshed. While this was always the case for scoped API keys, we were allowing users with 'Full access API keys' to copy them down at any point. We plan to remove this capability in the future, as making this change allows us to migrate all of our APIs keys to use a one-way hash and further protect against malicious use of the key.

**Starting Feb 5th 2018, the 'Full access API key' cannot be copied from NuGet.org**. While most of the packages pushed to NuGet.org now use a scoped API key and are not impacted by this change, users continuing to use our legacy 'Full access API keys' will need to securely stash the key before this date after which they will not be accessible. Please note that the 'Full access API keys' will continue to work just like they did before. We are only removing the ability to copy them down from NuGet.org.

If you have further question, please reach out to us by commenting on the [discussion issue](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5231) or send me an email at [anangaur@microsoft.com](mailto:anangaur@microsoft.com).
